imprint.note: According to Bentley, the "Prospectus was probably composed 'engraved', printed, and distributed rapidly in the autumn of 1793. No copy is known today, and the only information about it derives from Gilchrist" (*Blake Books*, page 450). The copy text presented here is from Alexander Gilchrist's *Life of William Blake, 'Pictor Ignotus'* volume 2 (1863); see note in Provenance.

objinfo.printdate: 1793 Gilchrist's *Life of William Blake* volume 2 was published in 1863.
objinfo.objsize: full page 20.1 x 11.9 cm. Given dimensions refer to the photographed pages of Gilchrist's *Life of William Blake* volume 2.
objinfo.numberleaves: 1 The transcription in Gilchrist is prefaced with an editorial note that claims the original Prospectus was "printed in blue on a single leaf". Bentley speculates that for the original "there were two plates, printed on recto and verso of one leaf, the second plate beginning with [paragraph] 5" (*Blake Books*, page 450) Objects 1-2 here are printed on the recto and verso of a single leaf in the Gilchrist copy.
objinfo.leafsize: 11 x 7.5 in. The editorial note from *Life of William Blake* volume 2 indicates that Blake's original leaf was "about 11 x 7.5 inches". Leaf dimensions for the Gilchrist copy are 20.1 x 11.9 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching *Life of William Blake* volume 2 is a letterpress book.
objinfo.inkcolor: blue The editorial note from *Life of William Blake* volume 2 indicates that the original relief etching was printed in blue ink. The Gilchrist book is printed in black ink.
objinfo.support: unknown *Life of William Blake* volume 2 is printed on wove paper
objinfo.watermark: unknown No watermark present in Gilchrist leaf.
objinfo.binding: presumably loosely bound *Life of William Blake* volume 2 is rebound in red boards, with spine reading "THE LIFE OF WILLIAM BLAKE / GILCHRIST / 2" in gilded letters.

provenance.name: Davis Library, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
provenance.note: There is no extant copy of Blake's etched Prospectus of 1793. According to Bentley, it was "probably composed, engraved, printed, and distributed rapidly in the autumn of 1793" (*Blake Books*, page 450). Alexander Gilchrist acquired a copy of the Prospectus through "Mr. Frost" and transcribed it in *Life of William Blake, 'Pictor Ignotus'* (London: Macmillan, 1863). In Gilchrist's editorial note for the Prospectus (page 263, see Object View Page), Mr. Frost is identified by Bentley as William Edward Frost of 8 Southampton Street, Fitzroy Square.

Blake's posthumous biographer Alexander Gilchrist died in 1861 before completing his biography of Blake, which was finished by his wife, Anne Gilchrist, with assistance from Dante Gabriel Rossetti and others (see also Bentley, *Blake Books*, pages 24-27).The title page of the 1863 volume containing the Prospectus reads: "LIFE / OF / WILLIAM BLAKE, / 'PICTOR IGNOTUS' / WITH SELECTIONS FROM HIS POEMS AND OTHER WRITINGS / BY THE LATE / ALEXANDER GILCHRIST, / OF THE MIDDLE TEMPLE, BARRISTER-AT-LAW; / AUTHOR OF "THE LIFE OF WILLIAM ETTY, R.A." // ILLUSTRATED FROM BLAKE'S OWN WORKS, / IN FACSIMILÉ BY W.J. LINTON / AND IN PHOTOLITHOGRAPHY; / WITH A FEW OF BLAKE'S ORIGINAL PLATES. // IN TWO VOLUMES. / VOL. II. // LONDON AND CAMBRIDGE / MACMILLIAN AND CO. 1863 // [The Right of Translation is reserved.]" Facing the title page is a frontispiece with two engravings. The first is from Blake's Chaucer, Canterbury Pilgrims; the caption reads: "Painted in Fresco by William Blake & by Him Engraved & Published October 8 1810 at Nº28 Corner of Broad Street Golden Square". The second is an 1861 engraving by Charles Simms.

The book was printed by R. Clay, Son, and Taylor, Bread Street Hill, London. Images presented here are from a copy in the Davis Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The Davis Library purchased this copy from the vendor Harding in 1940 for £1.8.

objnote.p: Original etching untraced; Blake's Prospectus is printed on one leaf, recto page 263 (Object 1) and verso page 264 (Object 2), in Gilchrist's 1863 edition of *Life of William Blake* volume 2, described in the note on Provenance in Copy Information.

The transcription includes only the text attributed to Blake, which is prefaced with a note written by Gilchrist and his posthumous editors, possibly including the hands of Anne Gilchrist, Dante Gabriel Rossetti, and others (see also Bentley,*Blake Books*, pages 24-27).The text not attributed to Blake can be viewed directly on the Object View Page.

lg.l: October 10, 1793.
The Labours of the Artist, the Poet, the Musician, have been pro- proverbially
verbiallyproverbially attended by poverty and obscurity; this was never the fault of the
Public, but was owing to a neglect of means to propagate such works as
have wholly absorbed the Man of Genius. Even Milton and Shakespeare
could not publish their own works.
This difficulty has been obviated by the Author of the following
productions now presented to the Public; who has invented a method of
Printing both Letter-pressLetterpress and Engraving in a style more ornamental,
uniform, and grand, than any before discovered, while it produces works at
less than one fourth of the expense.
If a method of Printing which combines the Painter and the Poet is a
phenomenon worthy of public attention, provided that it exceeds in elegance
all former methods, the Author is sure of his reward.
Mr. Blake’s powers of invention very early engaged the attention of
many persons of eminence and fortune; by whose means he has been
regularly enabled to bring before the Public works (he is not afraid to say)
of equal magnitude and consequence with the productions of any age or
country: among which are two large highly finished engravings (and two
more are nearly ready) which will commence a Series of subjects from the
Bible, and another from the History of England.
The following are the Subjects of the several Works not published and
on Sale at Mr. Blake’s, No. 13, Hercules Buildings, Lambeth.
1. Job, a Historical Engraving. Size 1 ft. 7½ in. by 1 ft. 2 in.: price 12s.
2. Edward and Elinor, a Historical Engraving. Size 1 ft. 6½ in. by 1 ft.
price 10s. 6d.
3. America, a Prophecy, in Illuminated Printing. Folio, with 18 designs.
price 10s. 6d.
